Barbara Diane Martin Richardson (born June 1943 in Detroit, Michigan) is an African-American singer; better known for being one of the original members of [MASK] singing group The Supremes.

She and her groupmates, Diana Ross (then known as Diane), Mary Wilson and Florence Ballard, signed a recording contract with [MASK] founder Berry Gordy on January 15, 1961 as The Supremes, a name that Ballard had chosen (as she was the only group member in the studio at the time) from a list provided by Motown songwriter, Janie Bradford, and became part of the Motown stable of performers.

She and her groupmates, Diana Ross (then known as Diane), Mary Wilson and Florence Ballard, signed a recording contract with Motown founder Berry Gordy on January 15, 1961 as The Supremes, a name that Ballard had chosen (as she was the only group member in the studio at the time) from a list provided by Motown songwriter, Janie Bradford, and became part of the [MASK] stable of performers.

Although Martin sang on many of the group's early singles, and most of the tracks on the group's first album, Meet The Supremes, she is not pictured on the album cover, and never received any royalties from [MASK] after 1962.
It was released in March 1969 on [MASK] in England (London Records in North America).

It was reissued in various regions, including the United Kingdom (home country), as In the Beginning (first in 1974) and then part of [MASK]'s Rock Roots repackaging series in 1976 before reverting to original title in recent reissues.
The album was released October 15, 1962 on [MASK] and was produced by Owen Bradley.
It officially impacted Urban radio on May 29, 2012 and was released on June 12, 2012 by [MASK] for purchase as a digital download.
The song serves as Coulter's debut release with [MASK], after parting ways with her former record label Shock Records in May 2011.
Hotter than July is the nineteenth album by American recording artist Stevie Wonder, originally released on [MASK]'s Tamla label on September 29, 1980.
Hotter than July is the nineteenth album by American recording artist Stevie Wonder, originally released on Motown's [MASK] label on September 29, 1980.
It was released on March 27, 1984 (see 1984 in music) on Harvest/[MASK] and Mercury.

In addition, the Motown-esque "Two Hearts", written in collaboration with [MASK] songwriter Lamont Dozier appeared on the original soundtrack album from Collins' 1988 film Buster, and Smokey Robinson & The Miracles' "Tears of a Clown" appeared as a B-side on the 2003 single "The Least You Can Do", and a live version of "My Girl" first appeared on the Japanese release Live from the Board in 1995 and later on the 2004 album Love Songs: A Compilation... Old and New.There are two editions of the album; one with 18 tracks and a limited Going Back Ultimate Edition 25-track CD/29-song DVD set.

The Funk Brothers played on [MASK] hits such as "My Girl", "I Heard It Through the Grapevine", "Baby Love", "Signed, Sealed, Delivered I'm Yours", "Papa Was a Rollin' Stone", "The Tears of a Clown", "Ain't No Mountain High Enough", and "Heat Wave".
"My Girl" is a 1964 standard recorded by The Temptations for the Gordy ([MASK]) label which became a number one hit in 1965.

"My Girl" is a 1964 standard recorded by The Temptations for the Gordy ([MASK]) label which became a number one hit in 1965.

Among the [MASK] songs Benjamin performed the drum tracks for are early hits such as "Money (That's What I Want)" by Barrett Strong and "Do You Love Me" by The Contours; as well as later hits such as "Get Ready" and "My Girl" by The Temptations, "Uptight (Everything's Alright)" by Stevie Wonder, "I Heard It Through the Grapevine" by Gladys Knight & the Pips and "Going to a Go-Go" by The Miracles.

Robert Willie White (November 19, 1936 – October 27, 1994) was an African-American soul musician, one of the guitarists for [MASK]'s in-house studio band, the Funk Brothers, White is best known for performing the guitar riff on The Temptations' number-one hit single "My Girl", but played the guitar on many successful Motown records, including "Can I Get a Witness" by Marvin Gaye, "You Keep Me Hangin' On" by The Supremes, "My Cherie Amour" by Stevie Wonder, "Something About You" by the Four Tops and "It's a Shame" by The Spinners.

Robert Willie White (November 19, 1936 – October 27, 1994) was an African-American soul musician, one of the guitarists for Motown's in-house studio band, the Funk Brothers, White is best known for performing the guitar riff on The Temptations' number-one hit single "My Girl", but played the guitar on many successful [MASK], including "Can I Get a Witness" by Marvin Gaye, "You Keep Me Hangin' On" by The Supremes, "My Cherie Amour" by Stevie Wonder, "Something About You" by the Four Tops and "It's a Shame" by The Spinners.
Time Out also features covers of [MASK] songs such as "For Once in My Life" and the Robinson-penned songs "My Girl" and "The Composer".

As with many Miracles songs, the lyrics of "My Girl has Gone" describe the end of the narrator's relationship with his lover: "My Girl Has Gone" has been covered by artists such as Etienne Daho, Edwyn Collins, Ken Parker, and [MASK] labelmate Bobby Taylor.
Their self-titled album debuted March 2010 with [MASK].

During the 1920s, Robison recorded extensively for [MASK], with scores of vocal recordings accompanying himself on piano (displaying his rather eccentric stride piano style), as well as "Deep River Orchestra" recordings using standard stock arrangements (including many popular and obscure songs) One recording was his fox trot arrangement of George Gershwin's Rhapsody In Blue on both sides of Perfect 14825 and Pathe 36644.
In 1926-1927, Robison recorded a series of 8 jazz songs under name of American Suite: He recorded for [MASK] and Pathé Records from 1926 to 1928.
Founded in 1992, the band recorded a self-titled album for [MASK], and charted with a cover of George Jones's 1955 debut single "Why Baby Why".
